title: Cultural or Religious Difference in Co-Parenting

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Main menu placeholder. Choose “Continue” to start the scene.

choices.label: Continue
choices.text: Continue

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Holiday Invitation
nodes.text: Your co-parent sends a message: “My family wants our child at the main holiday ceremony this year. It’s important to us.” The ceremony is tied to a tradition you don’t personally follow.

choices.label: Pause and ask for more details before reacting.
choices.text: You reply: “Can you tell me more about what happens there and what it would look like for our child?”

choices.label: Say no immediately — your values feel threatened.
choices.text: You respond quickly: “No. I don’t want our child involved in that kind of ritual.”

choices.label: Say yes, even though you feel uneasy.
choices.text: You write: “Fine, if it’s important to your family, we can do it,” while your stomach knots.

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: What the Tradition Means
nodes.text: Your co-parent responds with a voice note, sounding both emotional and hopeful: they explain stories from childhood, pressure from their parents, and how they worry their culture will fade out of your child’s life.

choices.label: Name both realities: culture AND the child’s comfort.
choices.text: “I hear this matters a lot to you and your family. I also want to make sure our child feels safe and not forced into anything scary or confusing.”

choices.label: Focus only on your discomfort.
choices.text: “This just doesn’t sit right with me. I don’t want our child learning those things.”

choices.label: Defer completely to their side to avoid conflict.
choices.text: “Do what you think is best, I don’t want to fight about this anymore,” you say, shutting down your own needs.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Decision Point
nodes.text: The holiday is a few weeks away. The bigger question is no longer just “yes or no,” but how to handle ongoing differences in culture and belief so your child doesn’t become the battleground.

choices.label: Suggest a structured conversation with clear goals.
choices.text: You propose setting a time to talk through long-term cultural and religious questions, not just this one holiday.

choices.label: Put it off and hope it sorts itself out.
choices.text: You postpone the conversation, telling yourself you’ll “deal with it later.”

choices.label: Return to menu instead of continuing.
choices.text: You pause the scenario here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Setting the Tone
nodes.text: You choose a calmer moment and suggest talking about culture and belief as an ongoing theme, not just a one-off crisis.

choices.label: Continue to Act 2.
choices.text: You both agree to sit down and map out how to share traditions in a way that feels fair and safe.

nodes.speaker: Mediator
nodes.title: Naming Core Values
nodes.text: You’re sitting with a neutral mediator (or imagine one in your mind if not in real life). They ask each of you: “What are your top two values you want your child to learn from your culture or beliefs?”

choices.label: Choose values that overlap (kindness, respect, family).
choices.text: You highlight shared values: kindness, respect, curiosity — things both traditions already encourage.

choices.label: Insist on distinct identity markers ("my" side vs "their" side).
choices.text: You focus on what separates you: “In my family we do X, not Y. I don’t want them mixing that up.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Designing the Holiday Plan
nodes.text: With values now on the table, you turn to practical questions: holidays, ceremonies, and family visits. The mediator asks: “How can your child experience both worlds without feeling like they’re betraying either parent?”

choices.label: Alternate major holidays and create a small ritual from each home.
choices.text: You suggest alternating who has the child on the main holiday each year and creating smaller traditions from both sides in every home.

choices.label: Give one side full control over holidays.
choices.text: You (or your co-parent) push for one tradition to “win,” framing the other as optional or secondary.

choices.label: Stay vague to avoid conflict; no written plan.
choices.text: You both shrug: “We’ll just see each year,” leaving the child in the middle of future tug-of-war.

nodes.speaker: Grandparent
nodes.title: Extended Family Pressure
nodes.text: Later, a grandparent corners you after a family visit: “We don’t want our traditions watered down. The child should be raised properly, like we did with you.”

choices.label: Set a respectful boundary about co-parent decisions.
choices.text: You answer: “We’re grateful for your traditions, but decisions about our child’s upbringing are between us as co-parents.”

choices.label: Side with the grandparent to avoid their criticism.
choices.text: You nod along, promising more participation without checking in with your co-parent.

choices.label: Argue intensely with the grandparent in front of the child.
choices.text: You snap back in front of your child, turning the hallway into a debate stage.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: How the Child Sees It
nodes.text: That night, you imagine your child’s perspective: different languages, foods, ceremonies — and the way adults talk about them. Are these differences framed as richness… or as a problem?

choices.label: Commit to reviewing the plan once or twice a year.
choices.text: You and your co-parent agree to revisit cultural and religious agreements regularly, updating them as your child grows and asks more questions.

choices.label: End the scene and return to menu.
choices.text: You pause here, letting the questions sit for now.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text: When you look back on these conversations, what do you hope your child remembers more: the arguments, or the way you tried to build a bridge between worlds for them?

choices.label: Notice the bridge-building moments.
choices.text: You focus on the times you named shared values and looked for both/and solutions.

choices.label: Notice how intense it felt — and plan support.
choices.text: You recognize how draining this is and consider getting cultural, legal, or therapeutic support to keep things grounded.
